body:
It isn't possible at the moment.  For S3 you can read the auth info from the environment or iam but you still need a config file.

It is a good idea though.  Perhaps the config file could be passed as an environment variable in some form?

I thinks that if all config variables from file may be specified via PREFIX that equal to profile name variable in env this is fine.
So all rclone stuff can work as before, but readed from env, after that from file...

This is now done.  Please see this beta

http://beta.rclone.org/v1.35-13-ge1a49ca/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

Here are notes from the docs

Environment Variables
---------------------

Rclone can be configured entirely using environment variables.  These
can be used to set defaults for options or config file entries.

### Options ###

Every option in rclone can have its default set by environment
variable.

To find the name of the environment variable, first take the long
option name, strip the leading `--`, change `-` to `_`, make
upper case and prepend `RCLONE_`.

For example to always set `--stats 5s`, set the environment variable
`RCLONE_STATS=5s`.  If you set stats on the command line this will
override the environment variable setting.

Or to always use the trash in drive `--drive-use-trash`, set
`RCLONE_DRIVE_USE_TRASH=true`.

The same parser is used for the options and the environment variables
so they take exactly the same form.

### Config file ###

You can set defaults for values in the config file on an individual
remote basis.  If you want to use this feature, you will need to
discover the name of the config items that you want.  The easiest way
is to run through `rclone config` by hand, then look in the config
file to see what the values are (the config file can be found by
looking at the help for `--config` in `rclone help`).

To find the name of the environment variable, you need to set, take
`RCLONE_` + name of remote + `_` + name of config file option and make
it all uppercase.

For example to configure an S3 remote named `mys3:` without a config
file (using unix ways of setting environment variables):

```
$ export RCLONE_CONFIG_MYS3_TYPE=s3
$ export RCLONE_CONFIG_MYS3_ACCESS_KEY_ID=XXX
$ export RCLONE_CONFIG_MYS3_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=XXX
$ rclone lsd MYS3:
          -1 2016-09-21 12:54:21        -1 my-bucket
$ rclone listremotes | grep mys3
mys3:
```

Note that if you want to create a remote using environment variables
you must create the `..._TYPE` variable as above.

### Other environment variables ###

  * RCLONE_CONFIG_PASS` set to contain your config file password (see [Configuration Encryption](#configuration-encryption) section)
  * HTTP_PROXY, HTTPS_PROXY and NO_PROXY (or the lowercase versions thereof).
    * HTTPS_PROXY takes precedence over HTTP_PROXY for https requests.
    * The environment values may be either a complete URL or a "host[:port]" for, in which case the "http" scheme is assumed.

issue.title: Feature Request: Scriptable Config

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
Feature Request:

It would be really nice to be able to do scripted installs / configs for use in containers.

Example:

On container init:
```
rclone config --interactive httpd --httpdPort 12345 --httpdRedirectOnDone {{IP}}:54321 --confoption NAME=ACD --confoption TYPE=ACD --confoption CLIENT_ID=value --confoption CLIENT_SECRET=value --confoption WHATEVER=value && \
rclone config --interactive httpd --httpdPort 54321 --confoption TYPE=crypt --confoption REMOTE=ACD:Vault --confoption FILENAME_ENCRYPTION=standard && \
mkdir /mnt/ACD_CRYPT && rclone mount ACD_CRYPT: /mnt/ACD_CRYPT &
```

Basically rather than provide CLI input, have the command launch the built in HTTP server that already exists, and wait for the needed input by the command. The individual commands can take the options provided and present back the HTTP server which options they still need filled in (dynamic input). Once submitted, the redirect kicks in and sends it to the next port / command (or something like that).

I'm going to start working on a small node.js service to manually build the rclone.conf in this manner, but I'd much rather it be handled natively. Right now I see now way to do remotely attended installs without the command line input.

Thoughts?

body: I'm confirm that this works fine.

Getting an error now when setting RCLONE_VERBOSE=true for the latest beta (99) [tested on both windows and linux]:

Invalid value for environment variable "RCLONE_VERBOSE": strconv.ParseInt: parsing "true": invalid syntax

Seems to be fixed though if I use 1 (since it's ParseInt) instead of true.
Yes that was an consequence of the new logging levels that the fact you can have `-vv` which is the same as `-v=2`.  Thanks for pointing it out!
i'm write drone ci plugin that uses rclone to sync artifact from builder to storage. does it possible to get list of all env variables that depends on storage ? (without to run rclone config)

issue.title: Beta: config variables

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
I can't seem to get rclone to recognize some of the environment variables outlined here:

https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/616

Example.
```

# env | grep RCLONE
RCLONE_STATS=5s
RCLONE_CONFIG=/home/robert/.rclone.conf
```

The RCLONE_CONFIG works but the RCLONE_STATS does not.  Also there is no way to tell what variables have been applied.  My suggestion is to include in the INFO or DEBUG output the parameters applied similarly to the echo'd command line already does.  That way we don't need to guess if there was a typo. :)  

```
rclone -vvv ls robacd:
2017/03/02 13:08:13 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.35-137-ge2f0fee" **starting with parameters** ["rclone" "-vvv" "ls" "robacd:"]
```

Can you also tell me why RCLONE_STATS doesn't work?  Is that a bug?

issue.title: Verbose Environment Variable doesn't work?

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?

Using the environment variable `RCLONE_VERBOSE=true` fails


#### What is your rclone version (output from `rclone version`)

```
# rclone version
2022/05/31 09:22:48 Invalid value when setting --verbose from environment variable RCLONE_VERBOSE="true": invalid argument "true" for "-v, --verbose" flag: strconv.ParseInt: parsing "true": invalid syntax
```

#### Which OS you are using and how many bits (e.g. Windows 7, 64 bit)

Linux NepheleTower 5.15.43-Unraid #1 SMP Wed May 25 11:54:05 PDT 2022 x86_64 AMD Ryzen 5 2600 Six-Core Processor AuthenticAMD GNU/Linux

#### Which cloud storage system are you using? (e.g. Google Drive)

Google Drive

#### The command you were trying to run (e.g. `rclone copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

`rclone copy /mnt/user/Media GoogleDrive:Media/`

#### A log from the command with the `-vv` flag (e.g. output from `rclone -vv copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

```
# rclone copy -vv /mnt/user/Media GoogleDrive:Media
2022/05/31 09:24:28 Invalid value when setting --verbose from environment variable RCLONE_VERBOSE="true": invalid argument "true" for "-v, --verbose" flag: strconv.ParseInt: parsing "true": invalid syntax
````

<!--- Please keep the note below for others who read your bug report. -->

#### How to use GitHub

* Please use the  [reaction](https://blog.github.com/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) to show that you are affected by the same issue.
* Please don't comment if you have no relevant information to add. It's just extra noise for everyone subscribed to this issue.
* Subscribe to receive notifications on status change and new comments.
